definitions.definition: to be considered to be something

examples.text: Does such an activity constitute a criminal offence?
Climate change constitutes a major threat to life.
His action was interpreted as constituting a threat to the community.
The census constitutes the principal source of official statistics.
The committee ruled that the US ban constituted an infringement of free trade.
The conference in itself constitutes a solid achievement.
This action constitutes a violation of international law.

definitions.definition: to be the parts that together form something

examples.text: Female workers constitute the majority of the labour force.
People under the age of 40 constitute the majority of the labour force.

definitions.definition: to form a group legally or officially

examples.text: The committee was constituted in 1974 by an Act of Parliament.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin constitut- ‘established, appointed’, from the verb constituere, from con- ‘together’ + statuere ‘set up’.
